SUBjECT: EXTREMIST INFORMANTS

EXTREMIST MATTERS

A recent article appearing in the Black Panther

Party (BPP) Cleaver Faction publication "Right On!" calls

for swift and unmerciful retaliation against current and

former extremist informants.

This article contains numerous

Intlammatory statements and may well signal the initiation

vell signal

of widespread retaliation against our informants.

Recently seized items 'from the Republic of New

Africa (RNA) included instructions to RNA members concerning

the indoctrination of those members suspected of being law

enforcement

informants.

These instructions basically involve

the completion of a personai questionnaire form and background

investigation.

Each agent should recognize the continuing possibility

of infiltrators within our extremist informant ranks.

There

have been attempts in the past to penetrate informant ranks,

and we can logically expect there will

be attempts in the

future in this regard. Therefore, all agents are reminded of •

• the importance of in-depth background investigation

and personal

knowledge of each informant, as well as the necessity for

careful verification and evaluation of information furnished

by extremist informants.

Each agent handling an extremist informant,

including extremist ghetto informants, should be thoroughly

alert to the absolute necessity for handling these informants

under the most secure conditions in order to eliminate the

possibility of these informants being exposed.

All agents

should also bring to the attention of their informants the

Republic of New Africa's methods of disclosing infiltrators

in order that our informants will be, forewarned.

cyanide or strychnine introduced

into the punch at anti-war group

meetings;

2) bombing

of the VVAW head-

quarters, the Guild Theatre, and

several porno shops;

3) bombings of the homes or offices

of anti-war leaders;

4) kidnapping or assassination of anti-

war leaders and activists;

5) fire bombing of vehicles and other

-property belonging to anti-war ac- .-

tivists.

By November and December 1971,

Busch continued, Godfrey had become

more ambitious: he wanted to acquire

drone planes which would carry pay-

loads of high explosives and phospho-

rus to be. dropped on the demon-

strators. In addition, Godfrey spoke of

using similar air craft, loaded

with

TNT. or C-4 plastique, to blow up Air

Force One and assassinate Nixon. The

• idea was to fly a bomb into the Presi-

dential jet as it landed either at Lind-

bergh Field or at El Toro Marine Base.

Busch claimed. that he had expressed

horror at the suggestion and told God-

frey he had lost his mind suggesting

anything as insane as an attempt on

the life of the President. Shortly there-

after, Busch and Godfrey parted ways

after the former grew suspicious that

he was being set up to take the rap on

the shooting of Paula Tharp. By

March 1972, he had left San Diego

and has not yet returned.

Even before Busch left the SAO,

the "Wanted for Treason" leaflet was

printed

and

distributed.

Another

former SAO member corroborates that

• in this same :erod-January-February,

1972-Godf.uy tried to find someone

to build a pline that would carry a

load of high explosives. (In addition,

he was apparently trying to obtain

another plane for the purpose of gas-

sing or bombing demonstrators on

ture, the SAO issued its April 1972,

bulletin, which began with a quote at-

tributed to Abraham Lincoln,

rant would not come to the United

States from across the sea. If he

comes, hell ride down Pennsylvania

Avenue from his inauguration and take

up legal residence of the White

House.

." Then followed detailed in-

structions on the manufacture of ex-

plosives which might be used to de-

stroy a large bridge (Tackwood's

two bridges on and off of Fiesta Is:

land) and

on various methods of

IA SINISTER PLOT?

Yas there a right-wing plot to

kill the President? Tackwood

says so. Busch says that FBI

informer Berry Godfrey talked about

it. The "Wanted for Treason"

poster

certainly indicated no loss of love be-

tween the extreme right and the Presi-

dent, and Godfrey was checking out

the availability of drone planes.

There are other curious, if admit-

tedly inconclusive, clues as well: The

day Nixon went to China, E. Howard

• Hunt was working as a public relations

man on a Julie Nixon Eisenhower TV

spot. He raged about the China trip;

"We should not send people to China,

we should send bombs to China." This

from a man supposedly involved in a

secret scheme to re-elect the President

by illegal means.

Or take this item which appeared in

the March 9, 1972, issue of the N.Y.

Times (10 days after Nixon's return

from China):

WAR ALERT SENT IN HOAX

BY A COAST GUARDSMAN

"New Orleans, March & (UPI)-An en-

listed man standing watch sent a hoax

message to ships at sea during Presi-

dent Nixon's visit to China, saying the

President had been assassinated • and

the Vice President had declared World

War III, the Coast Guard revealed yes-

terday.

"The authorities said that the hoax

message had not been taken seriously

and that the man who sent it from a

small Coast Guard station in Texas had

been confined and was undergoing

medicai evaluation.

"Tie message was sent February 27

by teletype to 22 ships in the Gulf of

Mexico."

There was no further story on this

that i have been able to find. If the

hoax message had gone out to a Polaris

submarine, Hunt might have gotten his

wish;

that bombs would be sent to

China.

Then, the L.A. Times reported on

July 13, 1973 that a former Minute-

man had requested political asylum in

Fiji, saying he had secret information

on Watergate and feared assassination.

All of this proves nothing, of

course, but it suggests that the Dirty

Tricks operation' may have been much

more complex than we have been led

to believe. Perhaps there was a plot to

kill Nixon, and then again Godfrey's

plot may have been a further hoax

aimed at discrediting the left and the

Democratic Party. What did Segretti

discuss with Godfrey, and why and

how did he meet Godfrey in the first

place? How did it happen that the FBI

financed a threat on the life of a Presi-

dent (a crime which carries a penalty

of up to five years in jail and a $1,000

fine)? In the past, the Secret Service

has taken such threats very seriously.

A check of the New York Times index

shows that at least 11 people were ar-

rested between January, 1972 and

May 1973 for doing much less than

Godfrey. Most seem to have been

psychopaths or drunks, with no posi-

tive plan-just verbal threats.

But then there are other instances:

Arthur Bremer's Ottawa visit on April

13-14, 1972, for example, when he

supposedly stalked Nixon. On May 30,

three bombs demolished the tomb of

the father of the Shah of Iran an hour

"before Nixon was scheduled to lay a

wreath there. On August 11, a certain

A. B. Topping was arrested in New

York after paying an undercover agent

$1,000 to kill Nixon. Topping, it

developed, was well-to-do, of the

American Nazi political persuasion,

and interested in having the President

killed the week after the pay-off. No

trial has been held. And then in late

May 1973, one of Nixon's helicopters

went down in the Bahamas. It subse-

quently came out that the President

has three helicopters ready at all times

and chooses which to use one minute

before the flight.

Watergate has uncovered

an ad-

ministration racked by factionalism.

Under Hoover, the FBI was at odds

with

the White House-10 such a

such testimony but would be somewhat reluctant due to my present

circumstances. It would appear to me that the interests of the Bureau

and the District Attorney's Office, as well as myself, would be better

served if this information was furnished by someone still connected

with the FBI. sodfrey's reliability should be a matter of record to

SECRET ARMY ORGANIZATION

UNDERGROUND BULLETIN

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS

JUNE 1972

" The people never give up their liberties but under some delusion". Edmund Burke

Fellow members,

At a recent meeting of the SAO General Staff a very important problem was discusse

and the decision to issue a new Organizational Directive made. The problem is thai ci

new members who join our organization and then immediately become totally inactive.

Typically these new members submit a well qualified application form together with

their membership fee. Unfortunately, after being accepted as provisional raembers

they never pay a month's dues or send in any report forms. It would really help us to

know why some of these people have acted in this way. Did our organization turn out

to be something different than they expected? Did they expect a fancy uniform and rifl:

to be handed to them on a silver platter? Or did they suddenly become afraid to stick

their neck out ?

Whatever the reasons, it isn't fair to our good members to waste time and money ca

those who do nothing to help or support the organization. Therefore, effective imtae-

iately, the following rules shall apply to such cases as mentioned above.

1. It, three months after submitting an application to the SAO and being accepted a:

a provisional member, the new member has not begun the basic correspondence iraiias

submitted monthly report forms, paid monthly dues, or provided a reasonable excuse

for not having done the above, their file shall be turned over to our Inteiligence Section

for special attention.

2. If, after six months, the member in question dosen't respond they shall be drog

from ouz rolls and their names shall be circulated to all members as a potential see:cia

risk.

We don't mean to imply that a member can't resign from the Secret Army Organianti

However, we do require that a member notify us of there intent and reasons for doing

If this new Organizational Directive applies to any member in particular let him take an.

and govern himself accordingly.

GENERAL STAFF - SECRET ARMY ORGANIZ I

HO

'O PREPARE CUNS FOR STOR

& BURYING

Although cosmoline can be purchased in many surplus stores, it may be more

practical to make your own from the following directions. One advantage to makilig

your own preparation is that it is much easier to apply while it is in a warm state.

Heat non-bleached petroleum jelly (ember-vaseline) in a small pan or can. Add

30 or 40 weight motor oil to obtain the proper consistency. Using an inexpensive

throw-away paint brush as an applicator, brush the warm solution over the weapon.

While the solution is still warm ii can also be poured into those hard-to-get-ai-areas.

One large jar of petzoleum jelly and approximately one-half quart of motor oil

is sufficient to prepare several yeapons.

When the solution has cooled it will set and form a protective coating over the

weapon which should then be wrapped in sheet plastic ( available in most hardware or

paint stores) or in a G. i. plastic gun case (available in most surplus stores ). Wrap

well and seal with black electrical or plastic tape. It is also wise to erclose a small

sack of silicagel crystals to keep the moisture out.: These crystals can be purchased

at any industrial chemical house or most applicance stores will give there away as they

come with cartons of appliances when shipped and they usually have an abundance on

supply.

Long guns which cannot be easily torn down can be stored in surplus rocket type

boxes readily available in most surplus stores.

Try to obtain aluminum or stainless

steel containers since they will not tend to rust when buried. 20mm ammunition cans

are adequate and a convienient size container for burying smaller weapons and other

items. They should be well sealed. The cans should be wrapped in plastic io prevent

rust.

GENERAL RULES OF GUERRILLA WAARE

1. The first rule of guerrilla warfare is co dispense with any

rule or set of rulas which results in routine of predictable activity.

Any time the enemy commander can

anticipate what the guerrilla band

will do next, he can then lay a trap by which his superiority of

numbers and equipment may be brought to bear upon them with devasta-

ting effect.

2. Militazy action by guerrilla bands cannot achieve maximum

effect unless intelligence and security capabilities are developed to

an equal degree of parfection, principally through the cooperation of

friendly nor-combatants.

Propaganda warfare is one of the guerrillas nost effectiva

weapons. It must be waged continuously to denoralize the enemy,

enlist support of the civilian population and to justify the existence

and actions of the guerrilla bands.

Each member of the underground novement must be rendered

Immune to the enemy's propagenda by continuous counter-propaganda.

They must realize that the enemy is certain to spread lies about their

leaders, to try and break the bands up by encouraging petty jealousies

and dissensions, to make them feel their fight is hopeless, to encourage

them to get on the winning side, to offer mercy and rewards to those

who voluntarily surrender.

Most of all enemy propaganda will be aimed

as destroying the individual organization member's faith in the honasty,

capability and true.motives.of other members of the underground nove-

•ment.

5. Sutprise is the main element of successful guerrilla warfare.

No matter how vigilant the enemy may be there will be times your band

can take him by surprise. Perhaps he is tired, pernaps sleeping,

perhaps he is in an area where he feels so completely safe that he

lets down his guard-- that's when you hit him.

•.

6. • Any guerrilla that wants to keep on living must constantly

remind himselt that war is not a sporting proposition-- never give the

communists an even break.

7. Genarally speaking guerrillas must work in small bands. From

five to fifteen is usual but even here its best not to get into a rut.

If the encay commander in your area knows you always work in small

groups he can then divide his available anti-guerrilla forces into

groups of 1s to 25 and thus cover more ground than if ha had to main-

tain groups of two or three hundred to make certain his forces would

always out number any guerrilla band they happened ucon.

8.

The guerrill leader must always keep its thinking one step

ahead of the enemys. Here are some examples:

14. Guerrillas should strike a violent lightning blow that leaves

the enemy stunned at least long enough for them to make a safe retreat.

15. In no case must tha guerrilias allow themselves to be drawn

into a long pitched battle with enemy troops.

16. So long as friendly forces of the conventional military

are able to retain their offensive potential it is expedient for

guerrilla forces to coordinate their activities with such friendly

troops.

17. Guerrilla bands must always nove in secret - their whereabouts

must always be hidden from the civilian population as well as from

enemy troops.

• 18. When possible always attack the enemy at places which are

distant from centers of population as this will reduce the possibility

of his making reprisals against friendly civilians.

Take his uniform and hide it carefully where it can

20. The guerrillas must always operate in their home territory

where they have intimate knowledge of their surroundings. If driven

from their own territory by a superior enemy force they should return

as soon as they safely can, provided that their main hide-out has not

been discovered and there is no chance of an enemy ambush.

21. Guerrillas must make every effort to stay friendly with any

civilian population in their territory as the civilians may be their

22. It is almost essential that the guerrilla band have at least

one secure hide-out where they can rest up, store their supplies and

care for their wounded. This hide-out may be in some large forest or

mountainous area but such is not always necessary. During World War II

one Russian guerrilla band had their headquarters in a storm sewer.

Another band headquartered in the basement of a hospital in one of the

smaller towns. Another operated from an abandoned coal mine.

23. The guerrilla band should have one or more alternate hide-outs

and be ready to move quickly and quietly to another prepared location

in case their main headquarters is discovered. To preserve maximum

security the location of these alternate hide-outs should be known to

the least possible number af their own band.

24. To operate successfully over long periods of time the

covering all of it with anti-guerrilla forces at one time.

History on

the Secret Army Organization

Oue early morning in February, 1970, a group of six Minutemen leaders from

four states met secretly in Northern Arizona to discuss the crisis that the arrest and

imprisonment of two top Minutemen leaders and the assassination of a third had

brought on the organization. Although some of these men had met before in their roles

as Minutemen group leaders, others were meeting for the first time.

After much discussion, two principal points were agreed upon. First, that the

Minutemen as a national coordination organization of militant right-wing groups had

effectively been destroyed by the pro-communist eiements inside the Justice Depart-

ment. While individual units still existed throughout the country, few had the financial

support or leadership to be really effective. Second, that the need for such a coordi-

nating organization wasgreater than ever in view of the increased revolutionary. activity

by communists in the United States.

With these two points in mind, suggestions were put forward on a course of

action to be followed. After a meeting that lasted all that day and far into the next

morning, an overall plan of action was finally agreed upon. All present agreed to

merge their individual units together and form a new organization under the command

of one leader elected from among themselves, with the other five to be members of a

General Staff that would advise and assist the new leader.

While retaining the basic programs and policies of the Minutemen, it was

decided that not only should this new organization have a different name, but also a

completely new chain of command and organizational structure. If the new organiza-

going to survive the attacks that befell the old one, a whole new approach

would be needed. Never again could the arrest or death of a few leaders be allowed to

cripple the entire organization.

For this reason it was decided that only a highly disciplined military type

orgainization with a definite chain of command would have any chance of success. This

then, was the beginning of the Secret Army Organization. Beginning with an original

force of hard core patriots that numbered fewer than two hundred, the Secret Army

Organization began the job of picking up the pieces and continuing to fight for national

and individual freedom.

Using this cadre of dedicated personnel as a nucleus, the

S. A. O. has been recruiting and training new members in the skills they will need as

the freedoin fighters of tomorrow.

The leaders of the S. A. O. have no idea of fighting a last ditch stand. We have

no desire to commit suicide ourselves or to let our members do so. We have a

strategy which we believe will ultimately lead to victory. Only one thing is essential.

We must start preparing and training NOW! We of the S. A. O. believe that our country

is worthy of any sacrifice. I you feel the same way, we invite you to join us.

The Secret Army Organization is the most active, most completely dedicated and

most selective in its membership of all the many patriotic organizations in America.

We are willing to make any sacrifice for our country and we fully expect that some of

us will have to make the ultimate sacrifice before victory is achieved. Our very lives

depend on each other. There is no place in this organization for bunglers, playboys or

lukewarm conservatives. If you join the Secret Army Organization, there might easily

come a time that your life would depend on how competently some other member had

on the domestic and world political

situation, it is probable that you have a lot to learn about the present threat our nation

there is undoubtedly a lot you can learn from the experts in our organization who have

developed and supervised our training program.

OUR NATION IS IN IMMEDIATE DANGER

It is possible that within a very few years, perhaps even within months, our

nation could be conquered and enslaved by the communists. To prevent this we must

know as much as possible about our enemies. Unless we know who they are and what

they are doing we will not succeed in our efforts to maintain a free America.

THE RESISTANCE MOVEMENT

In driving an invader from your land the resistance involved goes through three

stages of development.

1) The Underground Network

2) Active Guerrilla Warfare

• 3) Open or Conventional Warfare

The conventional warfare stage uses everything in the way of weapons that the

enemy does but must also have active guerrillas andunderground agents working against

the enemy, too. In the present state of military tactics conventional warfare cannot

succeed unless

these other two ingredients are used simultaneously.

The first step is to form an underground network. An active guerrilla system

must have the support of an underground network of approximately three times its own

size. This underground must supply the active guerrilla fighter with supplies, con-

cealment, information, etc. An underground network starts with departments of

intelligence, security and propaganda in that order.

Sabotage, espionage, subversion, infiltration, escape and evasion, training,

clandestine fabrication of supplies, counterfeiting enemy documents, recruiting, com-

munications and propaganda are other phases of underground activity. Each member

of the Secret Army Organization, to be effective, must have a working knowledge of

all these tactics as well as the military tactics more commonly associated with guerril-

ASSIGNMENT TO UNITS

Many people that inquire about membership in the Secret Army Organization

seem to have an idea that they will be immediately accepted into an active unit.

Look at it this way. Suppose you had spent a year or more carefully recruiting and

training until you had a hard hitting team where every individual was reliable, dedi-

cated, and had confidence in his fellow unit members. Wouldn't it make you mad to

have the national or regional organization assign some rank amateur to your unit

that you you knew little or nothing about?

Before any new member is assignedto an active unit or to an important under-

ground project, he mist undergo a period of training. During this training he will be

directed through the mails by an experienced member and some of his activities may

be observed by other members without his knowledge. Only when a new member

proves himself to be conscientious, trustworthy, self-disciplined and able to operate

effectively alone will he be accepted as a "'secure member" and invited to participate

with other unit members in a teamwork operation.

EXPENSES.

Unfortunately, most good things don't come cheap. Although we make every

effort to keep down the expense of membership in the Secret Army Organization, you

must expect to pay your own way.

Dues to the Secret Army Organization are $3. 00 per month. This money is

absolutely necessary for use to maintain our central files and headquarters, for

postage and printing, to finance our extensive intelligence network, and to maintain

training areas.

Each member will have other expenses depending on the type of activity he is

engaged in. Every member will be expected to buy his own gun, amnunition and

other basic combat equipment. During training the new member may be expected to

buy certain books or subscribe to certain magazines that his work requires. During

this time the new member will also be suppliedwith reading material on the strategy

and tactics of guerrilla warfare. Tois home work will make it possible for him to

fit in quickly to an active unit and participate effectively in actual maneuvers,

marksmanship training, etc.

Following this preliminary training a member may be either assigned to an

existing unit, assisted in organizing his own unit if he has shown sufficient leadership

qualities or become part of an underground network.

Upon your acceptance into the Secret Army Organization you will be given a

definite scries of projects described inwriting so you will know exactly what will be

expected of you.

We hope that you can succeed in this effort because your country desperately

needs patriots at this time.

On February 9, 1971

By JEROME

I contacted the mystery man last night at

Denny's Restaurant and it turned out to be ISAAC CANTRELL.

He told me that he previously lived in Arizona and

because of some trouble or difficulty there, moved

to

Los Angeles, California.

He said he believed he had been followed to

Los Angeles.

He subsequently moved to the San Diego area

and is now living in Alpine.

We talked about his recent arrest on charges

of violating firearms laws and he said the charges

against him have been dismissed. He said he thinks

the local authorities are still watching him, and that

they may try to arrest him again if they get the chance.

He said he still has most of his stuff for

working on firearms but indicated that the articles which

were confiscated at the time of his arrest had not been

returned to him.

As an additional note of interest, he told me

he had been in contact with BOB DE PUGH and WALTER PEYSON

at Phoenix, Arizona, approximately three months before

they were arrested.

I plan to proceed slowly in my contacts with

CANTRELL as he. may be a set-up for the local or state

authorities.

Jerome

EXPERIENCING COMMUNITY

THE TORI EXPERIENCE

The TORI community starts with several

experiences designed to build a sense of com-

munity, and to deepen personal growth.

Stemming from these experiences, the

community unfolds and emerges. Each mem-

ber has an opportunity to participate in this

process and to influence the unfolding' in

significant ways. The community becomes

, a powerful medium for personal change.

Members Have an opportunity to relate in-

tensely and openly to many others in a variety

of situatiorr.. They are free to try out new

ways of bi.hd and doing. Each participant

is responsilie for his own learning, and has

a variety of options and choices during the

weekend. Each person, in a significant sense,

creates his own experience and his own com-

munity environment.

The TOR! experiences (trust, openness,

realization, and interdependence) emerge

from the community interaction. They are

seen as central to the growth of the person

as well as to the development of community.

The basic TORI theory will be presented by

Dr. Jack R. Gibb as it is applied to the build-

ing of a sense of community in classrooms,

neighborhoods, congregations, families, and

the total school or business system.

Sandra La Boon, who will be conducting

the workshop, has worked with Dr. Gibb over

the past two years in a wide variety of group

NW 55009 DocId: 32989524 •Page 426

experiences. She has conducted groups with

the Center, Y.M.C.A.'s of Los Angeles and

San Diego and with the Methodist Church.

She is currently conducting research with Dr.

Gibb on the TORi theory.

DESIGN

The community is built upon 24 hours of

experiences over a three-day period. Parti-

cipants should plan to attend for all 24 hours.

No observers will be admitted although parti-

cipants will have freedom to participate in an

experience or not. We start after dinner, 7:30

PM on Friday. The Experience ends 5:00 PM

on Sunday. It is not necessary to stay over

night at the Inn.

CLOTHING

The dress should be comfortable and in-

formal, so you can sit on the floor and go

barefooted or wear socks.

SCHEDULE

Friday night from 7:30 p.m. - 11:00 p.m..

Saturday from 9:00 a.m. - 11:00 p.m.

Sunday from 9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.

MEALS

Meals are an integral part of the experience

and participants should plan to have all meals

with the group. There is no additional charge

for meals:

Cost of the training is S25.00.

The training will be in the evening November 22, 23, and 24th, 7:30 to 10:00 P.M. at the National Center

8080 El Paseo Grande, La Jolla, California.

have experienced a complete TORI weekend.

Experience.

A new year is upon us and there is much to report both good and bad concerning

our struggle for a free America.

Robery stemming from a series of very successful raids against the Socialist

Worker's Party ard The Young Socialisi, Alliance. The trials on all these charges

are still pending and Mi. Stewart 1s out on $30, 000.00 bond at this time. The

arrargements of legal council and tactics have kept a number of the staff here at

the National Coordinating. Center busy fo. quite some time. The cost of all this

as you can well imagine has been very high, but it is our sworn duty to do all we

can for Patriots such as Tom Stewart. As for more information about the case,

the legal aspects are better if we make no public comment. at this time,

Suffice it to say that the cases are heavy on our minds at this time.

The good news is somewhat more extensive, and is as follows:

The recruiting drive up and down the east coast is going very well and

we will soon be over our goals there.

2. The reorganization of the regions is nearing completion with only several

Regional direcrors left to be appointed.

3, The printing and reprinting of material is proceeding at a slow but

steady pace.

and recruiting. We uge all members to try and finish their training Phase as

of Practical Security measures which we feel all members should read and put into

practice as soon as possible.

April 7, 1971

Report of Jerome

PETER RUFLINGER was contacted this morning.

He

claims that there will be nine buses going from San Diego

State to the anti-war demonstration at San Fransisco on

the twentyfourth of this month. He said he will find out

later from where and when they are leaving and how many

people will be on the buses.

He knows about the $900 given

the demonstrators by the school and will try to find out if

they get any more money from other sources.

STAN MC DADE was also contacted this morning and

was accompanied by HOWARD CLEVELAND. It was learned that

NO DADE and HOWARD GODFREY were at Camp Pendleton yesterday

looking at the scrap parts pile of the Ordnance Disposal

unit there. They believe

there may be several complete

weapons of various kinds which could be made from the scrap

parts.

For this reason they are considering submitting a

bid on the some forty tons of

scrap which is to be sold.

It was learned that JOHN BUSE is also going to enter a bid.

MC DADE and CLEVELAND indicated they are going to

the deseret in the morning to spend several days doing some

shooting and exploring.

Jerome

exposing the internal working mechanism. The rear sight

on this rifle.

these parts. both have a regular toothed

nachine thread which was obviasly done to allow the rifle

JEROME

November 9, 1971

The SAO has received its first response

from the mallouts which were made in October.

this came from an individual named CHARLES MANLEVE,

2938 North Seventeon Drive, Phoenix, Arizona, 85015.

MANLEVE wrote his letter about two weeks ago expressing

Interest in the SAO and requesting more Information

about it.

Incidentally, we are about to lose BILL

CLay's old post office box at the Grossmont Post

Office Station. The building where the station is

located is to ba torn down and the post office boxes

are to be vacated by the 2oth of this month. It would

be helpful to obtain another post office box somewhere

else In CLAY's name to facilitate. the forwarding of

mails.

In talking with STAN MC DADE, I have learned

that MICKEY BURTON WAKEFIELD is no longer associated

with SMITH's Nazi group.

WAKEFIELD is oither married

to or has been living with a Mexican girl. The

official Nazi. Party policy is that people with American

Indian blood, including Mexicans, are an Inferior race

and therefore Nazi Party members

should have nothing

to do with them.

I understand that WAKEFIELD was ordered

to dump the girl he was llving with because of this

policy, but refused to do so. Consequently, he

either

quit or was thrown out of the Nazi Party by, SMITH.

MC DADE claimed that this same attitude on the

part of the Nazis toward people with Indian blood as

well as some other things which have happened has cost

SMITH most of the membership of his group. MC DADE

said that many of the Nazi Party members had Mexican

wives or girlfriends and that SMITH has been tolling

the members to get rid of them which has created hard

feelings.

I was also talking wiüh FRANK YACOPEC and

from him learned that his friend, ROBERT MAYER, 1s

quite knowledgeable about radio communications. MAYER

has been investigating the broadcasting seù up of radio

of the Banner Grade Highway. We took the wall down and

nothing. It is the intention of this group to chock

By Jerome

GEORGE HOOVER was at my house this morning and

• Left with me a sample of the metal which he alleges is

stolen government gold. He said he has come to the con-

clusion that the metal must be a gold-platinum alloy because

of the high melting temperature it has.

MAYER went by the house at 3121 Beech Street in an attempt to

get at the printing press located there to destroy it.

Apparently, they were not able to accomplish anything there as

I have not heard of anything happening.

VACOPEC is now gone to Los Angeles, california, on

a trip following which he will travel to Gary, Indiana, to

visit with his brother. He said he will try to do some

recruiting for the SAO while there, and will

put up SAO

stickers and leaflets wherever he can.

a letter to DAVIS frOM JESSE CLAYBURN SIEVENS.at Silver Springs,

group hated ROBERT DE PUGH and stated that he was in contact

with GLENN JACKSON and JOHN ZEMANEC of the American Volunteer

I received a telephone call last night from LYLE

MANNING at Richfield, Utah. He has telephone number 801-896-

5262, and gave me his address as Post Office Box 412, Richfield,

Utah. He told me he is now employed taking care of the fair

grounds and race track at Richfield. MANNING claimed that he

and "DOC" ROBERIS are trying to form a right-ving activist

group at Richfield and asked me to send him all the Minuteman

literature that I could get for him. He also indicated

that he and ROBERTS will be visiting the San Diego areạ

about the middle of January, 1972. He said the purpose of

their trip will be to obtain all the .30-06 and .308 caliber

ammunition that they can find. He asked me to start looking

around for this ammunition for him.

I visited TOM FORREST's place last night and learned

that somehow he is obtaining a large number of the top halves

for M-16. rifle receivers. Apparently the only real difference

between the M-15 rifle, which is semi-aucomatic, and the M-16

rifle, which is fully automatic, lies in be top half of the

receivers. He claims to have no trouble selling all these

items that he can get ahold of and he must have a good source

for suchweapon parts.

members of the SAO who are known to me:

JERRY LYNN DAVIS

January 17, 1972

by JEROME

•

Last night BARRY GODFREY told that earlier in the

day two San Diego, California, Police Department, detectives

had core to his house questioning him about the shooting

incident at the residence of Professor PETER BOHNER on

January 6, 1972. GODFREY said the detectives names, SANDERS

and SHIVELY, came on very strong as though GODFREY was a self-

admitted member of the SAQ. They asked what he knew about

the shooting incident and whether the SAO had been involved.

He told them he did not know anything about the shooting

except when he had read the paper, and he did not elaborate

on the SAO. They then asked him whether he had any 9 mm.

weapons to which he replied he did not and that he did not like

that caliber. Following that, they asked him if he knew anyone

in the SAO who had anything to do with the incident and GODFREY

said that he did not. The detectives then said the shooting

incident was a very bad deal, and GODFREY agreed with them

stating it was very unprofessional and that if someone had

really wanted to do something to Professor BOHNER, they could

have easily taken the front half of his building off.

GODFREY said the detectives were somewhat interested

in his automobile, and explained to him that they had pre-

viously observed him visiting at the residence of JERRY LYNN

DAVIS.

January 18, 1972

by JEROME

Last evening BARRY GODFREY told me that SAM DAVIS

had been interviewed by the same two detectives who talked

to GODFREY the day before. He said they asked SAM if he was

a member of the SAO and he said he was. They then asked him

if he was responsible for the shooting incident at Professor

BOTHER's house or if he knew of anyone who was involved in

the incident to which DAVIS replied no. He then told the

• detectives that if the SAO, as an organization, had wanted to

do something like that, Professor BOHMER would have been leveled

to the ground. They then asked DAVIS many questions about the

SAO to which he answered as truthful as he was able, and

particularly they asked if the SAO intended to put out more

bulletins similar to the one it had prepared on Professor BOHER.

DAVIS told them that the SAO did intend to print such bulletins,

which caused the detectives to ask him if the same number

of bulletins would be sent out or if more or less would be

sent. DAVIS said more and indicated that the next bulletin would

be sent to about three hundred people; the one after that to •

about five hundred people and the one after that to about

one thousand people. According to DAVIS, this caused the

detectives to become very upset and they said they did not

think sending out so many bulletins was a very good idea as

## Page 626

January 20, 1972

bY JEROME

I have learned that the Bulls Eye Gun Shop in El

Cajon, California, has been closed as it was not making much

money. BILL GUIETTE, the former manager, is now hanging around

with a friend named LARRY BROWN at the Jiffy Machine Shop.

Most of the gun shop inventory, including many weapons, is now

located in GUILTTE's garage at his home.

TOM FORREST has a business establishment named

the Tom Forrest Company located in the Midway Industrial Center

on Kurtz Street just off Rosecrans. He is usually there most

afternoons and evenings.

I was at TORPEST'S place last night and learned

that he had many bi-pods fro M-14 rifles, which were probably

stolen. He said he got them from a

I Marine who had just walked

in off the street with then. Furthermore, I was digging

around in FORREST's backs room, and found there in the

neighbor-

hood of one hundred boxes of what appeared to be barrelled

M-14 actions. I opened one

of the boxes sufficiently to see

what was inside, and assumed that the rest of the boxes had

the same thing in them. In my opinion, it is likely that these

barrelled actions were suppose to have been destroyed at a

place like Iort Ord, but somehow, got into FORREST's possession

instead.

JANUARY 28, 1972

I was told by BARRY GODFREY that he and SAM DAVIS

went to see LOU CONDE this morning to ask him to help finance

some of the SAO's activities. When contacted, CONDE donated

a complete "Angry Thirteen" military radio set to the SAO

together with all of the antennas, crystals, the hand cranla,

generator repair kit, etc. This is to be picked up later.

He also agreed to send the SAO some money and said he would

get support for the organization from certain other people

and would put the So in contact with the underground Cuban

Refugee Organization, Alpha 66.

Apparently CONDE is running for election to the

County Board of Supervisors for the seat now held by WALTER

SCHEIDLE. He claims he has the backing of both the La Jolla

and Clairemont Town Councils. He is also supposed to be

chairman of a couple of local parent associations and is

highly regarded in the Republican Party for his previous

campaign efforts in behalf of Governor REAGAN.

CONDE claimed to. DAVIS and GODFREY that a former

Special Agent of the FBI at San Diego named "BOB SUNDQUIRT",

JANUARY 31, 1972

BY JEROME

I was talking yesterday with GEORGE HOOVER.

He has been spending a great deal of time at the residence

of RICHARD and GENEVIEVE FLEURY in Harbison Canyon across

the road from the Gunsmoke Ranch.

JERRY LEE BUSCH has also been spending a lot

of time there and lives with the FLEURYs part time.

Another individual who also has been spending

a considerable amount of time with the FLEURYs is a person

whose name is DICK DEXTER OF DEXTRAND. DEXTER is a member of

the Swallows Nudist Camp which is also located across Harbison

Canyon Road from the FLEURYS. DEXTER has apparently been trying

to work a way into some of the Right Wing activities which other

people at the FLEURYs are involved in and is suspected of

being an infiltrator, mostly because of the fact he lives

in Ocean Beach.

## Page 689

FEBRUARY 2,

BY JEROME

Yesterday, I accompanied STAN MC DADE to keep

• an appointment with GENE BOSARTH, the San Diego State

College student who has indicated a willingness to

furnish

information about New Left oriented activities at San Diego

State College to the SAO. BOSARTH claimed to have written

letters to Governor REAGAN regarding the PETER BOHER situation

• at State College requesting that some action be taken against

BOHMER. MC DADE backed off a little when BOSARTH mentioned

he had been contacted by the local office of the California

Bureeu of Criminal Investigation and Identification and even

went so far as to suggest that we might do the same thing.

Later in the day, I learned from both MC DADE and

SAM DAVIS that there was a type of vigilante meeting in Lakeside

several days ago of local individuals and groups. It appears

this meeting was held to discuss and plan out actions to be

taken to keep hippies and other undesirable individuals out

of the Lakeside area during the Republican National Convention

in San Diego this summer.

It was brought to my attention that the semi-annual

Yuma Gun Show will be held on the 25th, 26th, and 27th of

February. I was told that CY ANDERSON will be coming down

from Seattle to attend this gun show and will come to San

Diego several days in advance to take care of some business here.

FEBRUARY 4, 1972

BY JEROME

÷

PAUL RUPLINGER told me yesterday he was at an

NSWPP meeting last Wednesday night at the San Diego unit

headquarters. He said about 20 people were in attendance

and had come to hear a speaker from Los Angeles, known as

"Captain K" tell about recent confrontations by the NSWPP

and the Jewish Defense League at Los Angeles. He said

VIC WALTON was one of those people he recognized as being

in attendance at this meeting.

I was also told yesterday by GEORGE HOOVER that •

an NSWPP member named WAKEFIELD had been booted out of the

organization for engaging in unauthorized ativities such as

MARCH 6, 1970

BY JEROME

I attended the Cuc planning meeting in Balboa

Park last night.

Igot there at about 7:10

• but the meeting did not get going til 7:35.

There were approximately 50 to 60 people present.

•The meeting was chaired by the Reverend BILL COATS.

•I saw FREITJOF THYGISON "there, however, he left early,

in disgust.

1 aLso recognized ALAN STANCLIFF, SYLVLA

SHAPIRO and BERNIE SENTER in the crowd.

Also present

was a young white individual in his early 20s with long

dark brown hair. He was wearing a fatigue jacket with

red stars

on the collar.. I heard him refer to as "ILOYn"(howe/l

and he said he was a representative of the San Diego

Street Jounal.

Baraman

Two other persons who spoke at the meeting

claimed to be representatives of MDM. One was a clean

white male with a military look, medium build, about

5'9" tall.

He has light colored hair and wearing

• a Mao-

tse-tung

style quilted cap. The other vias also about

5'9" tall, medium build, long blond hair who wore gola

rimmed glasses; a red jacket and camouflage pants.

It was decided there would be city wide peace

activity. during the week of April 13 to 18, 1970. However,

there was a lot of arguments and backbiting as to whether

actual peace march should take place on April 15 or

April 18, 1970.

It was agreed the march should probably

start aù noon and that it would be a flop if less than

8,000 people showed up.

The MDM representative with the Mao tse-tung

cap was screaming that people from the military and people

with jobs could not come of the rally was held on the 15th,

a Wednesday, and finally the MDM and Street Journal prople

walked out of the meeting.

After they left, there was

some discussion about a possible compromise where the rally

would be held on wednesday evening and servicemen wouls

be bussed

to it.

Before they left, the people from the Street

Journal announced that they had moved into new offices

but were evicted the same day after the police department

talked to their new lardlord. They said that they had an

offset place which they would use to make posters

for.

the April demonstration.

3/12/70

JEROME

A demonstration began today at San Diego State

College and students from the school took over part of

'the administration building and at one time there were

close to 700 students there with more expected to arrive

after 4:00 p.m, when classes were out. It has the earmarks

of lasting for

a long time.

The demonstration was touched off at about noon

by a speech given by KARL KELIER at a rally on the library

loan.

The students are protesting administrative action

taken by the school against four professors there.

Food including apples, oranges, carrots, punch

and loaves of bread is being passed around in the building

and is apparently being prepared at the Wesleyan Foundation

Building.

Signs have been put up in the building indicating

that the restrooms have been "liberated" and are now co-educational.

Some marijuana was seen being passed out free. About 100

students have elected to stay over night and are going home

in shifts to obtain sleeping bags and other items.

The demonstration appeared to be well planned and

some organizers, including RHETTA ALEXANDER for one, were

seen communicating with walkie-talkies. Other persons

observea taking part in the demonstration wee RON BREEN,

STEVE NYSTROM,

BERNIE SENTER, ALAN STANCLIFF, SUKUMO and

FRIETJOF THYGESON.

3/16/70

JEROME

I stopped by State College about 11:00 p.m. last

night. There were about 75 students in the halls

of the

administration building who were painting 30' long banners

and placing them on the walls of the administration building.

They were also printing leaflets announcing a rally at noon

today o campus.

LEON NOWER was observed there holding hands

with a young girl. BERNARD STREIFF, the french student

who claims to have participated in the french student

revolt, was also there.

Jerome

APRIL 15, 1970

BY JEROME

I met an interesting individual at BILl CLAY'S

house last night.

He is, called "The Judge" and his

first name is JERRY.

He i's about 5'10"

, to 5'11" tall,

230 pounds, has heavy built, ruddy complexion and is

35-45 years old.

He has black hair which is receding,

a pug nose, round face and heavy jowels. He carries

a brown and .32 automatic pistol and is apparently

an excellent shot.

He said he spent 8 years in military intelligence

following which he worked for the CIA and then for the FBI

assassin for the CIA.

and I was told he was good at make-up and voice imitations.

He said he had worked at Hollywood as a bit player.

He claimed that when he worked for the FBI

at San Diego, he was assigned to watch TROY HOUGHTON

and that he quit at about the time of the watts riot

in LosAngeles.

He said he was never a close acquaintance

of HOUGHTON but he had followed HOUGHTOr a lot and

came to the personal conclusion HOUGHTON was a Communist.

He seems almost to have convicted CLAY of this also.

had been meeting some known members of the Communist

Party. BUSH and CLAY were thinking DE PUGH may have

become aware of this and had HOUGHTON eliminated.

If

this is so, cuat said he vias thinking about contacting

DE PUGH and humbly apologize for po trying to break away

from the national Mi organization.

"The Judge" is supposed to be from Virginia, although

he has no accent, and apparently hates colored people. He

speaks fluent German and Spanish.

CLAY stated he believes one of the leading Leftists

in the area is MORRIS KOMINSKY who lives at. 400 Last Franklin

Street, Elsinore, ralifornia.

He has written a book which

is being advertised in papers like the Iree Door and the

Street Journal. KOMINSKY allegedly moved in high circles

in the Federal

and local Governments at one time and has

supposedly been visited on numerous occasions, high placed

Government people, including Congressien, Senators, and Presi-

dents such as TRUMAN, EISENHOWER, and KENNEDY.

CLAY said he wants some

local Right Wing neonle

to visit KOMINSiN and somehow get his signature.

about 5'9" tall, curly black hair which has a lot of gray

posture, as he slouches and has a pot belly.

From his

statements, I gathered that he is very much in favor of

what the San Diego Street Journal is doing. He said he

and claimed

as we repnrted ourselves to be fans of the Street Journal,

ON MAY 8, 1970,

BY TEROME

Today, I went to a meeting at the Greek

Bowl at State Collese to find out about the march route

for the anti-var demonstration to ba held tomorrow.

There were about 60 people in attendance at the meeting

which started about 3:00 PiN.

these included Bat coAls,

LUMbURG, and a reverend from the Wesleyan Foundation.

There was a big hassle about the choice of the

march route; the ChiC wanted to march from Horton Plaza in

downtown San Diego, along Broadway to the 1lth Naval District

Headquarters for some speeches and then to the old ferry

landing for a rally.

SMS and the other students voted this down and

CMC almost walked out. A long debate followed resulting

considerable uneasiness between CMC and SMC. ALAN STANCLIFF

was selected as monitor captain.

College where another anti-war rally was taking place and

picked up some leaflets, which are attached.

We noted that they were passing out free food.

BIlL ChAY went and got some syringes and FRANK YACOPEC

bought some pickles which were injected with rubbing

a Icohol and castor oil and were passed out to the students

who were seen eating them. It is not noted if any of

Today, approximately 5,000 people, mostly long

•hairs and hippies participated in an anti-war march and

demonstration in San Diego.

They marched from the downtown

area to Balboa Park where a rally was held.

It was noted

that MDM marched as a separate unit in the

• demonstration

and was trying to cause trouble.

BILL CLAY, who was present recognized two "long

hair" Minutemen in the middle of the MDM group trying to

in the

CLAY had mobilized between 100 and 200

right wing individuals and there appeared to be a lot of

There also appeared to be about the

same number of Marines out waiting for a fight and several

were seen in front of the federal Building holding coke

bottles and waiting for the hippies. to come along.

I was told that the demonstration march was stopped

at the 5th Avenue Bridge over Interstate Highway 5 and that

BILL CLAY and his friends were the ones who stopped it.

BILL CLAY got into a discussion with FREITJOF

THYGESON, who appeared

to be very disgusted with the repetitive

nature of the demonstration and the location of the march.

Persons observed present at the demonstration

included HERBERT MARCUSE, BILL MILSON, WARREN NIELSEN,

PETER CARTWRIGHT, BILL COATS and ALAN STANCLIFF.

SYLVIA SHAPIRO was the Master of Ceremonies and

STUART INNERST was the main speaker. JAN DIEPERSLOOT and

RON BREEN also spoke. Dr. GEORGE ABBOTT was also there and

had organized an emergency medical corps using walkie-talkies

and with ambulances available.

Sergeant BILL COOK of the La Mesa Police Department,

and the Captain of the Security Guards at Convair (NFI)

were there and were taking good photographs of the demonstration.

It was learned that BILL CLAY "liberated" two rolls

REPORT BY JEROME

September 18, 1270

This morning I went to Message Information Center,

arriving there at about 10:30 AM. Already there were TOM

HYDE and a young high school kid named STEVE (LNU) who was

learning how to be a MIC operator.

I shot the breeze with HYDE for about an hour.

He told me he is now Acting Co-ordinator for MIC. He said

, there will be a change in MIC leadership as he, HYDE, will

be leaving in about a month. He did not say where he is

going.

supposed to be going to work full time with the San Diego

Street

Journal. According to HYDE, both the Street Journal

and Sunrise are supposed to be out again in a

few weeks.

HYDe said there will be mostly new people on the Street Journal

staff.

HYDE also talked about MIC's "Fugitive File"

• This

file contains information on how to help deserters and draft

dodgers get out of San Diego. He said the file had been taken

out of MIC and hidden because many of the people connected

with this work had been questioned about it recently by the law.

perome

He also said that apparently some of the servicemen who

Jerome

Last Friday, I went up to Jullan to the Mountain

Market Grocery Store

and met the owner, whose name is MARGIE

MC NICKLES.

MC NICKLES sells Minutemen, Ku Klux Klan and

other similar literature and material across the counter at

her store.

She is also working with the Patriotic Party in San

Diego and told me that she is going to try to form a chapter

0s the Patriotic Action Legion in San Diego.

Her son is supposed to be President of the Young

Republicans Organization at Grossmont College.

She told me that ROBERT DE PUGH has been on trial

Tor all the federal charges against him at Albuquer She said

Mexico, and

has been held in the City Jail there.

DE PUGH was to have been sentenced on 10/9/70 and said that

he was asking for a total of ten years each on nine separate

counts.

MC NICKLES said that the jailors at the Albuquerque

City Jail are taking very good care of DE PUGH as most of

then are very sympathetic to him: MO NICKLES also made a

statement to the effect that if DE PUGH is sent to Leavenworth

he will never get there which I took to mean that there may.

be an escape attempt.

MC NICKLES also said that she knows JOHN ZEMANEC of

AVG and GLENN JACKSON of the Patriotic Party at LOS Angeles.

She showed me an open letter which DE PUGH wrote to ZEMANEC

telling him to get completely out of right-wing activities.

She also had some other stuff which she claimed to have just

recently received from de PUGH.

MC NICKLES also told me there is a commune at Julian

not far from her place.

she said these people are long hairs,

but clean and drive nice cars. She said they moved in several

months ago paying $32,000 cash money for the house. She said

I have not been in contact with LOU CONDE in some-

however, I understand he is still politically active

CONDE has always had a reputation as a "blabber

mount"

, but actually only talks about little things which

are not very important. CONDE is a clever, dynamic, ambitious

and hardworking person. He has a lot of money and is very

willing to put some of it into right wing activities.

CONDE has many Cuban exile contacts and is a Cuban

himself. In particular, he is close to the Alpha 66 group

and can get them out to do things for him..

CONDE is in very tight with the local tuna boat

association and I would imagine he also has many contacts

among the shrimpers and tuna sievers.

This is because he

has a marine engine and shipfitting business and does much

work for the fishing. boats.

: It is entirely likely that CONDE may be involved in

some way with Illegal arms shipments on some of these fishing

boats between here and some latin American countries. If this

is happening, I doubt that the weapons are coming to the

probably being purchased here and shipped to Cuban guerrilla

organizations in Central and South America. It is also possible

that CONDE may secretly be doing some work to arm some of the

tuna boats to protect them against seizure by such countries

as Peru and Ecuador. He mentioned something about this to me

about a year ago.

ON JANUARY 18, 1971, BY JEROME

I have learned that sometime ago, FRANK YACOPEC

and JERRY TARTAGLIO were in contact with a retired Army

colonel who claimed he was some kind of an aide to General

PATTON, or otherwise connected with him, when PATTON was

Involved in desert maneuvers and training in the Palm Springs,

California, area at about the beginning of the second world

war.

According to what this colonel said, PATTON and his

troops received urgent orders requiring them to pack up and

ship out to go overseas with only two days notice. Because

of

such short notice, rather than taking their heavy equipment

and supplies with them, they simply abandoned and buried them

inmolesale quantities.

I understand that many trucks and

tanks were part in ravines and gullies and dirt was bulldozed

over them.

There are a lot of recorded instances where people

have found such buried supplies in the desert out beyond

Palm Springs.

This area is still all Government property

that is very

little inhabited any any time. Apparently the

Government has either lost its records, forgotten about; or

simply doesn't care about all the stuff that is supposed to

be buried out there.

In particular, this colonel told YACOPEC and TARTAGLIO

about a large concrete bunker with big double steer doors which

he said was filled with ammunitions and explosives and also

buried.

He apparently told TARTAGLIO and YACOPEC how to locate

the bunker and I understand that they went out to the desert

• and after digging through about six feet of sand, actually

round the steel doors to the bunker. Following this, they

covered the bunker up again and have not been back since.

On the 27th of this month, a group Including YACOPEC,

BARRY GODFREY and PETER REPLINGER are going to go out to the

desert to try and relocate the bunker and dig it out. I

understand that REPLINGER has access to a portable jackhammer

and some other heavy equipment which he will use to dig out

the bunker.

If It 1s at all possible, I will try and go along

with them to see what they actually find.

ON JANUARY 26, 1971, BY JEROME

This morning I answered an ad in the newspaper

and purchased a .22 calibre Remington rifle for $20.00.

I bought the gun from a Negro individual by the name of

MAURY (ph) (LNU) who is presently residing at 5880 University,

Apartment #9. He looked to me to be in his late 20's, about

5' 9" tall and slender and was wearing a goatee beara and

very much, both in physical

He told me he had just moved to San Diego from Los

Angeles and is looking for work.

While I was at his apartment, I noticed he had large

quantities of Black Panther and other black militant literature,

Including books by ELDRIDGE CLEAVER and copies of the Black

Panther Party newspaper.

In addition to the .22 calibre rifle, he also had

in his possession a •32 calibre automatic pistol which is

cheap imitation of the French MAB and is made in Spain.

It has been learned that there is a San Diego Police

Department officer named BOB SISK who claims he is a member of

the Minutemen organization.

I was in contact with GILBERT MC GILL Sunday. He is

still employed at the Telephone Company. He told me he has

been helping to tap some telephone lines and that it is still

a common practice for Telephone Company employees to listen in

on telephone conversations in the san Diego area.

Regarding the possibility of a big Minutemen meeting

during the middle of December, 1970, I was unable to get in

touch with BILI CLAY during almost the entire last half of

December and it is possible he may have gone to the Chicago

meeting. It is also possiblo that SAM DAVIS may have gone as

I am frequently unable to contact him for several days at a

time.

Assistant Attorney General

Internal Security Division

NOTE:

William Francis Yakopec, a member of the paramilitary,

ultraconservative, anticommunist Secret Army Organization (SAO), is

on trial in Superior Court, San Diego County, San Diego, California,

on a charge of attempted murder. As indicated above, defense

witness Calvin Hendell Fox has alleged the FBI planted a document

in his personal files on 5/18/72. Fox in May, 1972, was identified

by former Bureau informant Howard Barry Godfrey as one of the most

rabid and violent new members of the SAO. Godfrey furnished infor-

mation that Fox, immediately after the attempted assassination of

Presidential candidate George Wallace, indicated he was going to

Washington, D. C., to do some demonstrating of his own.

Investi-

gation was

instituted to ascertain description and license number

of Fox's automobile and other background information in order to

carry out responsibilities regarding protection of Presidential

candidates and high Government officials.

SA Arthur J. Hooper

and

former SA Steven I. Christensen on 5/18/72 made inquiry at Fox's

service station and an employee of Fox looked through Fox's file

cabinet in an attempt to obtain the license number of Fox's auto-

mobile. There is no indication documents in this file cabinet were

extensively examined by the Agents or that anything was placed in

these files. San Diego teletype 9/21/72 contained SA Hooper's

proposed testimony which will refute Fox's testimony. This matter

has been coordinated with SA James I. Williamson, Office of Legal

Counsel.

This is to confirm that on September 19, 1972,

Special Agents William C. Patterson and James I. Williamson of

this Bureau had a conference with Mir. Sol Lindenbaun of your

office regarding whether certain records of this Bureau pertainin

to a former Bureau informant were to be produced in answer to a

subpoena duces tecum in Superior Court, San Diego County,

San Diego, California, in the trial of Milliam Francis Yakopec.

The subpoena duces tecum was served on Special Agent Earl M.

Petersen on September 18, 1972, after he had testified in the

trial of Yakopec, a menber of the white extremist Secret Army

Organization. Yakopec is charged with attempt to commit murder

and possession of explosives based on information obtained by

former Bureau informant Howard Barry Godfrey.

Mr. Lindenbaum instructed that Special Agent Earl M.

Petersen under the instruction of the Attorney General was to

decline to furnish the records in Superior Court, San Diego County,

San Diego, California, which the subpoena duces tecum ordered

produced.

Our San Diego Office has advised that Assistant

United States Attorney Robert H. Filsinger on September 19, 1972,

met

in the chambers of Superior Court Judge Robert W. Conyers

and

advised him that the records requested by the subpoena duces

tecum would not be produced in court. Judge Conyers indicated

the court accepted the decision not to produce the records and

that Special Agent Petersen's testimony in this regard would not

be necessary.

Purpose of this memorandum is to obtain authority to

contact Internal Security Division, Department of Justice, concerning

testimony of former Special Agent (SA) Steven I. Christensen, who is

to appear as witness for the prosecution on 9/7/72 in Superior Court,

San Diego County, San Diego, California, in trial of George Mitchell

Hoover, a member of the white extremist Secret Army Organization

(SAO) .

Rand,

sets ilen

Former SA Christensen was assigned to the San Diego Office

and

was handling former extremist informant Howard Barry Godfrey,

a member of the Minutemen and an officer in the SAO. In January,

1972, Godfrey reported that on 1/6/72 SAO member Hoover

fired a

• shöt

into the residence of New Left activist Peter Bohmer which wounded

Paula Tharp. Christensen received this information from Godfrey and

subsequently furnished the information to the San Diego Police

Department (SDPD). Godfrey's identity as the source of the informa-

tion was not furnished the SDPD at that time.

MAINS REC-65

15713577-51

In June, 1972, Godfrey reported that SAO member William

Francis Yakopec was responsible for bombing a san Diego movie theater

on 6/19/72 and was in possession of explosives. Based on information

furnished by the informant Godfrey the SDPD arrested Yakopec,

Hoover

and four other SAO members. Yakopec and Hoover were charged with

attempted murder and possession of explosives. In order to obtain

successful local prosecution of Hoover, Yakopec and the other SAO

members, the informant Godfrey was turned over to the SDPD. Subse-

quently, it was learned the gun used in the shooting of Tharp had

been stolen by Godfrey and that the gun was given to former

SA Christensen after the shooting. The gun was retained in

Christensen's home until turned over to the SDPD one fizi Desi

Christensen on 7/6/72, after admitting to the Special Agent

in Charge, San Diego, that he had made false entries in the Bureau

records regarding the gun, submitted his resignation. Christensen

indicated he had retained the gun as Godfrey had indicated he did not

desire to testify and therefore was attempting to protect the informant

Godfrey. Although not subject to subpoena as he is residing outside

California, Christensen has tentatively indicated a willingness to

testify in the trial of Hoover.

A list of the prosecution's questions

•to be asked Christensen was furnished (see attached questions) since

information obtained by Christensen while he was an FBI Agent cannot

be revealed in state court without prior authority from the

Department.

This matter has been coordinated with SA James L. Williamson,

Office of Legal Counsel. Questions to be asked by the prosecution

appear to involve no objectionable area. Testimony of Christensen

could possibly cause adverse comments in the news media regarding

his concealment of the gun which had been used in the commission of

a felony. The alternative is not to authorize his appearance which

would have an adverse effect on the prosecution of Hoover. In view

of the above, it is recommended no objection be made to the testimony

of Christensen.

ACTION:

Attorney General, Internal Security Division of the Department,

will be contacted to obtain authority for the testimony of former

SA Steven I. Christensen on 9/7/72 in Superior Court, San Diego

County, San Diego, California, in line with the above.

SECRET ARMY ORGANIZATION (SAO)

The Secret Army Organization (SAO) is an

anti-communist, paramilitary organization

formed in 1971 in San Diego, California.

It intends to conduct intelligence-type

operations and to offer training in urban

guerrilla warfare to be used against "Left-

Wing groups" and suspected enemies of the

United States.

The above description of the SAO was furnished by

Howard Barry. Godfrey, a San Diego City fireman, who during

June and Jily, 1972,

testified before the San Diego County

Grand Jury regarding his knowledge of the activities and

members of the SAO. Godfrey testified that over the past

year, he has served as an officer and was a member of

SAO in San Diego. He also testified that for the last

five years he has acted as an informant for the Federal

Bureau of Investigation (FBI).

It is noted that lloward Barry Goafrey, for

-a-number of years, voluntarily furnished

the FBI information Iegarding the identities

and activities of extremist groups in the

San Diego area. 'His information has been

reliable and as an interested citizen he

volunteered his knowledge and

services to

This document contains neither recommendations nor conclusions

of the FBI. It is the property of the FBI and is. loaned to your

agency; it and its contents are not to be distributed outside

your agency.

History of the Secret Army Organization

One early morning in February, 1970, a group of six Minutemen leaders from

four states met secretly in Northern Arizona to discuss the crisis that the arrest and

imprisonment of two top Minutemen leaders and the assassination of a third had

brought on the organization. Although some of these men had met before in their roles

as Minutemen group leaders, others were meeting for the first time.

After much discussion, two principal points were agreed upon. First, that the

Minutemen as a national coordination organization of militant right-wing groups had

effectively been destroyed by the pro-communist elements inside the Justice Depart-

ment. While individual units still existed throughout the country, few had the financial

support or leadership to be really effective. Second, that the need for such a coordi-

nating organization wasgreater than ever in view of the increased revolutionary activity

by communists in the United States.

With these two points in mind, suggestions were p't forward on a course of

action to be followed.

After ameeting that lasted all that day and far into the next

morning, an overall plan of action was finally agreed upon. All present agreed to

merge their individual units together and form a new organization under the command

of one leader elected from among themselves, with the other five to be members of a

General Staff that would advise and assist the new leader.

While retaining the basic programs and policies of the Minutemen, it was

decided that not only should this new organization have a different name, but also a

completely new chain of command and organizational structure. If the new organiza-

tion was going to survive the attacks that befell the old one, a whole new approach

would be needed. Never again could the arrestor death of a few leaders be allowed to

cripple the entire organization.

For this

reason it was decided that only a highly disciplined military type

orgainization with a definite chain of command would have any chance of success. This

then, was the beginning of the Secret Army Organization. Beginning with an original

force of hard corepatriots that numbered fewer than two hundred, the Secret Army

Organization began thejob of picking up the pieces and continuing to fight for national

and individual freedom. Using this cadre of dedicated personnel as a nucleus, the

S. A. O. has been recruiting and training new members in the skills they will need as

the freedom fighters of tomorrow.

The leaders of the S. A. O. have no idea of fighting a last ditch stand. We have

no desire to commit suicide ourselves or to let our members do so. We have a

strategy which we believe will ultimately lead to victory. Only one thing is essential.

We must start preparing and training NOW! We of the S. A. O. believe that our country

is worthy of any sacrifice. If you feel the same way, we invite you to join us.

SECRET ARMY ORGANIZATION

The Secret Army Organization is the most active, most completely dedicated and

most selective in its membership of all the many patriotic organizations in America.

We are willing to make any sacrifice for our country and we fully expect that some of

us will have to make the ultimate sacrifice before victory is achieved. Our very lives

depend on each other. There is no place in this organization for bunglers, playboys or

lukewarm conservatives. If you join the Secret Army Organization, there might easily

come a time that your life would depend on how competently some other member had

learned his job.

Unless you are especially well informed on the domestic and world political

situation, it is probable that you have a lot to learn about the present threat our nation

faces. Unless you have had many years experience in actual underground warfare,

there is undoubtedly a lot you can learn from the experts in our organization who have

developed and supervised our training program.

OUR NATION IS IN IMMEDIATE DANGER

It is possible that within a very few years, perhaps even within months, our

nation could be conquered and enslaved by the communists. To prevent this we must

know as much as possible about our enemies. Unless we know who they are and what

they are doing we will not succeed in our efforts to maintain a free America.

THE RESISTANCE MOVEMENT

In driving an' invader from your land the resistance involved goes through three

stages of development.

1) The Underground Network

2) Active Guerrilla Warfare

3) Open or Conventional Warfare

The conventional warfare stage uses everything in the way of weapons that the

enemy does but must also have active guerrillas and underground agents working against

the enemy, too. In the present state of military tactics conventional warfare cannot

succeed unless these other two ingredients are used simultaneously.

The first step is to form an underground network. An active guerrilla system

must have the support of an underground network of approximately three times its own

size.

This underground must supply the active guerrilla fighter with supplies, con-

cealment, information, etc. An underground network starts with departments of

intelligence, security and propaganda in that order.

Sabotage, espionage, subversion, infiltration, escape and evasion, training,

clandestine fabrication of supplics, counterfeiting enemy documents, recruiting, com-

munications and propaganda are other phases of underground activity. Each member

of the Secret Army Organization, to be effective, must have a working knowledge of

all these tactics as well as the military tacties more commonly associated with guerril-

la activities.

DISPERSED TEAM

When discussing a Secret Army Organization "Combat Team", we usually think

of a small group of people who live very close to one another. Such an arrangement

has certain advantages, such as ease of communication and travel for collective

, training and team operations, but there are also several disadvantages.

Among the disadvantages are these: Team members may be well acquainted

with only a small geographical area. If-forced to leave-this area the team may be

placed at a serious disadvantage. It is harder for a team of SAO members who

live closely together to keep from attracting attention, thus unit security may be

poor. If one o ember of the team is ever discovered and arrested by the enemy,

chances are that all members of the team will be rounded up together.

These considerations have caused us to experiment with a new arrangement that

we refer to as a "Dispersed Team"'. Such a team has the same number of members

(usually six) as a regular Combat Team. Each team is split into two sections as is

the old team. • The members have the same type of individual specialties and duties.

The big difference lies in the fact that the team members may be located over

a comparatively larger area - perhaps as much as 25 to 50 miles in diameter. In

urban areas one team member may live in each of six different cities. Thus the

team may range over a fairly large geographical area with at least one team member.

being familiar with the immediate territory through which they are traveling.

When active as part of an underground movement (as opposed to the classical

forms of guerrilla warfare) the Dispersed Team has several other advantages..

• For example, if one member of the team gets too "hot" in his area, he automatically

has five other hide-outs to which he can go for assistance or to which he can send

his family for temporary safety. The Dispersed Team can conveniently cover a

larger area in the fields of recruiting, psychological warfare, and propaganda.

Operations of sabotage, surveillance and harassment of communist personnel,

raids, and other combat type operations can be successfully conducted while moving

a minimum of people over a minimum distance.

During the present period of deliberate delay the activities of the team will

naturaily be different from some future period in which all out warfare between our

. organization and our country's communist enemies develops.

If the team is to achieve its ultimate objectives the following activities must

be provided for: (1) organization of and within the team, (2) communications between

the team and higher command, (3) maintaining secrecy of team members, (4) main-

-taining a continucus and effective propaganda effort, (5) obtaining the necessary sup-

plies and equipment for present and future needs, (6) training of the team in general,

and of individual members in their own specialties.

When the required personnel are not available to form a full team, a three

-_mas section should be formed. When additional people are recruited the unit can

then be expanded in an orderly fashion.

BOOBY TRAPS

Broadly defined a booby trap can be any kind of apparatus

In which a reaction unfavorable to the enemy is brought about

when he unintentionally makes some act which triggers the re

action. The most common types of booby traps used in warfare

Involve an explosive charge which is set off by movement of &

trip wire or the moving of some object which is connected to

the trigger mechanism.

On occasion the explosive charge may be replaced by

signal flares, gas, smoke or other chemical agents. The trigger

mechanism may be either electric, mechanical, thermal or chemical.

ELECTRICALLY OPERATED TRIGGERS. Such trigger mechanisms

'are very easily arranged wherever a supply of electric blasting

caps are available and also a suitable source of electricity.

One of the most common electric type booby traps is to simply

Interrupt the electrical circuit in some building so that when

the lights are turned on the explosive is detonated. This

simple procedure applied to an automobile with a few sticks of

dynamite has marked the end of more than one gangland hoodlum.

"He who accepts evil without protesting it is really cooperating with it."
