organizing your underground group

The most effective underground movements are built step-by-step. They begin with

-intelligence networks and the dissemination of propaganda. Gradually the movement

includes passive, then active sabotage. Finally it develops into full time underground

warfare. There may be times when surprise attack or special circumstances may

roquire immediate armed resistance but such resistance cannot be fully effective un-

til the intelligence and propaganda services can be developed to an equal extent. If

proper sources of information are developed prior to military action many possible

traps and expensive mistakes can be avoided.

Once a country is at war or occupied by an enemy, recruiting new underground men -

bers is a very hazardous occupation. Suspicion and fear lie like a blanket over the

people. Neighbors are afraid to be seen talking together. Even friends become

guarded in their talk.

These are the reasons why we advocate forming your group now - while you can still

do so in comparative safety. It is like insurance purchased in hopes that you will never

collect. Il the need for active combat never comes this will still not be time wasted.

You will surely gain true friends. You will surely profit by a better understanding of

your neighbor's point of view. You will certainly add to your appreciation of the

courage and dignity of your fellow Americans.

It is best if your group can be made up of people who have known each other previously

and who already respect one another's ability and loyality. Unfortunately this is not

always possible. So long as personal existence is possible most people will try to

"exist" under the yoke of slavery. Only here and there will you find a person with the

courage and conviction to join in active resistance against the enemy.

The communists are well aware of these facts. They are constantly trying to ferment

distrust among the peoples of the free world. Even here in the United States many in-

telligent and responsible people are losing their confidence in one another, in their

THE

OF AMMONIUM NITRATE IN HIL

1 EXPLOSIVES

• Ammonium nitrate is a common fertilizer used on farms throughout the United States

and most foreign countries. It is readily available from farm agencies, general stores,

fertilizer companies, etc. in most farming communities.

Most people know that ammonium nitrate can be used as the basis for various high

explosive mixtures.

Little information has been available as to the best proportion,

uses and means of detonating these mixtures.

Depending on the method of manufacture ammonium nitrate may occur as irregular

grains, flakes, small crystals or small round "prills". Any of these types can be used

but prilled ammonium nitrate is most efficient. Fortunately, the prilled type is also

the most common.

Explosive mixtures may be made by mixing ammonium nitrate with such organic

compounds as fuil oil, powered coal, lamp black, etc. Its quite possible that powered

sugar, starch, and many similar compounds could also be used but further experiment

ation is needed. Ammonium nitrate itself is extremely difficult to detonate.

The most common and probably the best all round mixture consists of 94% prilled

ammonium nitrate aud 6% fuel oil. In this case the term fuel oil can include No. 2

diesel fuel, kerosene, light lubricating cil, etc. The only requirements are that it be

thin enough to be readily absorbed by the rather porous prills of ammonium nitrate and

on the other hand it must not be so volatile as to evaporate easily.

The amount of fuel oil can vary from 2% to 13% and the mixture will still explode

provided that a strong detonater is used. Maximum explosive force is achieved between

5% and 6%. These percentages are figured by weight.

Presumably the best percentage

of lamp black or finely powered coal would be approximately the same.

Because these mixtures are comparatively insensitive they all require a rather

strong explosive to start the detonation.

In nearly all cases a one pound stick (2x8 inches)

of 60% dynamite will suffice. The dynamite itself must, of course be detonated by a

suitable blasting cap. One stick of 40% dynamite does not have enough power to detonate

an ammonium nitrate-fuel oil mixture reliably. If this is all that is available, three

sticks tied together should be used.

The shape as well as the size of the detonater has an effect.

• For example, if an

eight inch stick of dynamite is cut into four inch pieces and these are tied together it

effectively decreases the length and increases the diameter of the detonating charge.

This will increase its reliability over that achieved by a single eight inch stick.

'Several other fact.

erfect the efficiency of AN-FO (ar...

um nitrate-fuel oil)

mixtures.

Among these are the amount of explosive used in a single charge, degree

of confinement, moisture content, particle size temperature, etc.

AN-FO mixtures are commonly used in mining rock or ore from large open pits.

In this application, holes are drilled back into the rock and the AN-FO mixture is poured

into the holes. Normally, the ammonium nitrate and the fuel oil are carried separately

to the mine and are mixed together just before they are used. The holes into which the

AN-FO mixture is poured are usually several feet long. In this case the diameter of the

hole has considerable effect on the explosive force generated. A hole diameter less than

•three inches will not explode with sufficient force to carry itself along the bore hole. The

maximum detonation velocity requires that the bore hole be at least six inches diameter.

In using smaller amounts of AN-FO mixtures the charge should be kept approximately

equal in its length, width and depth. In practical application a container about the size

of a five gallon gas can is as small as can be used. Charges the size of a 55 gallon drum

can provide much more explosive force in proportion to their weight. A small amount of

AN-FO requires just as strong a primer to detonate as does a larger amount.

Close confinement is required to achieve maximum explosive force from AN-FO

mixtures. In mining operations the rock surrounding the charge provides this confine-

ment. To be exploded above ground the AN-FO mixture should be confined in an iron

pipe not less than three inches in diameter and preferably larger. Since these mixtures

are "pushing" type explosives rather than "shattering" types they must be properly placed

to achieve useful results,

• Suppose the objective was to destroy a large bridge. A dozen five gallon cans of

AN-FO mixture are available to do the job. If these are set in the middle of the bridge

or between the girders and "exploded" little if any real damage will result. In this case,

a tunnel should be dug through the dirt behind the concrete abutment at one end of the

bridge. Depending on the width of the bridge all twelve cans of explosive could be packed

tightly together or they could be spaced three to four feet apart. In either case each can

should be provided with its own primer and all the primers should be tied together with

two lengths of prima cord.

Moisture content of the ammonium nitrate is very important. This chemical absorbs

moisture from the air quite easily. After being mixed with the fuel oil it is protected

from this to a considerable extent. For maximum explosive effect the AN-FO mixture

should contain no more than 4% water and if the moisture content exceeds 7% it may not

explode at all. If it is suspected that the AN-FO mixture may be damp, double the size

of the detonater.

For military use, suitable charges could be made from dry ammonium nitrate mixed

with the proper amount of fuil oil and then placed in water tight containers. These con-

tainers should provide some means of quickly placing the detonater into the approximate

center of the charge just before it is to be used. The usual cost of ammonium nitrate

is about $6.00 per 100 pounds.

SECRET ARMY ORGANIZATION

UNDERGROUND BULLETIN

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS

JUNE 1972

"! The people never give up their liberties but under some delusion".

Edmund Burke

Fellow members,

At a recent meeting of the SAO General Staff a very important problem was discussed

and the decision to issue a new Organizational Directive made. The problem is that of

new members who join our organization and then immediately become totally inactive.

Typically these new members submit a well qualified application form together with

.....their membership fee.

Unfortunately, after being accepted as provisional members

they never pay a month's dues or send in any report forms. It would really help us to

know why some of these people have acted in this way. Did our organization turn out

to be something different than they expected ? Did they expect a fancy uniform and rifle

to be handed to them on a silver platter? Or did they suddenly become afraid to stick

their neck out ?

Whatever the reasons, it isn't fair to our good members to waste time and money on

those who do nothing to help or support the organization. Therefore, effective immed-

iately,, the following rules shall apply to such cases as mentioned above.

1. If, three months after submitting an application to the SAO and being accepted as

a provisional member, the new member has not begun the basic correspondence training,

submitted monthly report forms, paid monthly dues, or provided a reasonable excuse

for not having done the above, their file shall be turned over to our Intelligence Section

for special attention.

2. If, after six months, the member in question dosen't respond they shall be dropped

from our rolls and their names shall be circulated to all members as a potential security

risk.

We don't mean to imply that a member can't resign from the Secret Army Organization.

However, we do require that a member notify us of there intent and reasons for doing so.

If this new Organizational Directive applies to any member in particular let him take notice

and govern himself accordingly.

GENERAL STAFF - SECRET ARMY ORGANIZATION

HOW

*ARE GUNS FOR STORAGE "

BT YING

Although cosmoline can be purchased in many surplus stores, it may be more

practical to make your own from the following directions. One advantage to making

your own preparation is that it is much easier to apply while it is in a warm state.

Heat non-bleached petroleum jelly ( ember-vaseline) in a small pan or can. Add

30 or 40 weight motor oil to obtain the proper consistency.

Using an inexpensive

throw-away paint brush as an applicator, brush the warm solution over the weapon.

While the solution is still warm it can also be poured into those hard-to-get-at-areas.

One large jar of petroleum jelly and approximately one-half quart of motor oil

is sufficient to prepare several weapons.

When the solution has cooled it will set and form a protective coating over the

weapon which should then be wrapped in sheet plastic ( available in most hardware or

paint stores) or in a G. I. plastic gun case (available in most surplus stores ). Wrap

well and seal with black electrical or plastic tape. It is also wise to enclose a small

sack of silicagel crystals to keep the moisture out. These crystals can be purchased

at any industrial chemical house or most applicance stores will give them away as they

come with cartons of appliances when shipped and they usually have an abundance on

supply.

Long guns which cannot be easily torn down can be stored in surplus rocket type

boxes readily available in most surplus stores.

Try to obtain aluminum or stainless

steel containers since they will not tend to rust when buried. 20mm ammunition cans

are adequate and a convenient size container for burying smaller weapons and other

items. They should be well sealed. The cans should be wrapped in plastic to prevent

rust.

Buried containers should have at least one and a half feet of earth over them. One

should be careful also in selecting an area to bury material. Areas that could be flooded

during even the most unusual weather conditions should be avoided.

Buried containers should be in such a position that they can be found easily and

quickly without the use of maps. This can be done by correlation between two or more

specific points that will remain in tact, such as trees, large rocks, etc. To assist

your memory, paces should be marked off by using the day, month, and year of your

birth or that of some family member which you can easily remember.

Another suggestion would be for burying containers along or near roadways which

are marked with numbered signs indicating the footage of road per county. These signs

are permanent, but it must be remembered that the state has a 500 foot right away on

most roads which means the brush may be cleared or the existing road might be widened.

All material which is buried should be checked within three to six weeks for settling

or sinking of the ground.

THE COMBAT TEAM

General Outline

The "Combat Team" is the smallest organizational unit used by the Secret

Army Organization. When organized in the proper manner it is capable of opera-

tional initiative when detached from the parent organization. When developed to

its highest degree of efficiency the Combat Team is almost totally self-sufficient

and able to perlorm any one of several missions. To attain these aims the follow-

ing elements are essential:

a.

Equipment should be well-chosen and standardized as much as pos-

sible.

b.

c.

d.

Communications, internal and external, must be capable of rapid

transmission, be varied in nature, and be exercised with prime

emphasis on security.

Internal coordination should be automatic in response. Confidence

among members of the team must be developed.

Selection of each position on the team should be based on psycholog-

ical aspects as well as technical competence.

e.

f.

g.

Training of the men in each function should be at regular intervals

and continuous.

Field problems should be given dry runs in detail:

The logistics problem should be studied with care, and made simple

and direct.

Each team will have a "leader" (Lieutenant) and an "assistant leader"

(Sergeant). These men shall be given special training by the Secret

Army Organization at "leadership seminars".

Team "marshalling points" should be selected in advance and be

well defined. Practice "alerts" will determine the team's efficiency

in response and security.

Terrain familiarity within the expected operational radius of the

team must be developed.

Weapons familiarity must be obtained throughlive firings at various

targets. Team action must be stressed as well as individual com-

petence.

The team leader should see that a constant flow of information is

provided to team members on the ideological struggle. This will

help induce the proper frame of mind in each member.

Team missions and targets must be identified and the proper train-

ing equipment made available for each assignment.

IM.

" The te

leaders will be responsible for antaining the overall

security of the unit. Personal feelings should not affect decisions

involving reprimand or dismissal of men from the team for reasons

that endanger its operation or security.

Intelligence gathering as an important part of each team member's

duties should be stressed. Information on the location and move-

ments of local communist and left-wing enemies of the organization

should be sent to either Regional or General Headquarters.

The team leaders will be responsible for maintaining contact with

higher command and for the transmission of orders from same.

ORGANIZATION

The "Combat Team" will consist of six men. These six men will be divid-

ed into two sub-teams (Sections). Number One Section wiil consist of the Team

Lieutenant and two other team members. Number Two Section will consist of the

Team Sergeant and the two remaining team members. When completely assembled

the unit will act directly under the command of the Team Lieutenant. When split

into sections the Team Sergeant will carry out the orders of the Team Lieutenant

during missions but will be in immediate command of the Number Two Section.

In the absence of the Team Lieutenant the Sergeant will take command of the Unit.

TRANSPORTATION

Transportation of the Combat Team will be effected by the use of two car-

riers. Interception and/or destruction of one carrier will not, then, immobilize

the team. In addition, each carrier can serve as a scouting element for the other.

Motorized carriers should be as inconspicuous as possible and still serve their

purpose. Jeeps and pickup trucks should be used only where such vehicles are

owned and used commonly by the general population or where the terrain makes

their use necessary. Most often an ordinary passenger car will suffice. The

model selected should have a good road clearance so it can be used on dirt roads.

Tire chains (if needed), hydraulic jacks, extra gas, water, and suitable tools

should be stored in the vehicle.

TRAVEL PROCEDURES

Underway, Carrier #1 will lead and Carrier #2 will trail, The "interval"

will vary with conditions. In cities close-aboard trailing willbe used. Open road,

by day, will require an interval of approximately 300 yards. At night this will

be reduced to approximately 100 yards. During travel, all equipment (especiaily

arms and ammunition) should be kept out of sight. Special team equipment and

weapons should be locked in the trunk of the vehicle until needed. The trunk key

should be carefully hidden so as to make it difficult to search the trunk in case

law enforcement agents should stop the car on some pretext with the intention of

searching it illegally.

NOTE:

George M. Hoover, a member of the paramilitary, ultra-

conservative, anticommunist Secret Army Organization (SAO), was

identified by former Bureau informant Howard Barry Godfrey as the

individual responsible for the wounding by shooting of Paula Tharp

on 1/6/72 in San Diego, California. This information was

furnished the San Diego Police Department (SDPD). On the basis

of information furnished by the informant, Hoover was arrested

on 6/26/72 by the SDPD and charged with attempted murder and

improper storage of gunpowder in excess of 20 pounds without a

license.. The San Diego Division has advised that a search warrant vas

obtained by the SDPD based on information furnished by the informant.

Special Agents C. Jordan Naylor and Earl M. Petersen have been

subpoenaed to appear as indicated above as witnesses. Special

Agent Naylor originally opened an informant case regarding the

informant Godfrey but has not contacted Godfrey in past five years.

Special Agent Petersen has been the alternate Agent contacting

Godfrey for the past two and one half years and was assigned this

informant since 7/6/72.

This matter has been coordinated with

Inspector John A. Mintz, Office of Legal Counsel.

SECRET ARMY ORGANIZATION

EXTREMIST MATTERS

Source One and Source Two, both of whom have

furnished reliable information in the past, advised on

August 3, 1972 that no such organization as the Secret

Army Organization exists in the Los Angeles area, as far

as they are able to determine. All of their information

•concerning such a group comes

from newspaper articles,

which reflect San Diego has such an organization.

Sources

added there is no past information concerning such a group.

Both sources advised they could furnish no information

that one Sam Napier might be connected with the. Secret

Army Organization:

Source Three, who has furnished reliable infor-

mation in the past, has previously advised that Sam Napier

had joined the Secret Army Organization and was reportedly

one of the assistants in helping Jerry Lynn Davis organize CALIF,

the Secret Army Organization in the Los Angeles area.

On June 19, 1972, Sam'Napier, Jr., was interviewed

at his residence, 4806 West 137th Street, Hawthorne,

California by Special Agents of the Federal Bureau of

Investigation.

Napier advised that in the past he had belonged

to a group called the American Nazi Party and that they had

changed their name to the National Socialist White People's

Party (NSWPP) and that he had resigned from this party in

1968.

At his resignation, he directed a letter to the NSWPP

local chapter, a copy to the National Headquarters of the

NSWPP, and a copy to the Los Angeles Federal Bureau of

Investigation.

SECRET ARMY: ORGANIZATION

The National Socialist White People's

Party, also known as

the American Nazi

Party, American Nazis, and the George

Lincoln Rockwell Party, was organized

on February 26, 1956 at Arlington,

Virginia, based upon the concept of an

international "National Socialist"

movement as espoused by the German

Nazi Party headed by Adolf Hitler.

The

organization supports and follows

the

line of hatred against Negroes; Jews,

and communists through various pro-

paganda media seeking a legitimate

dominant political party in the United

States

and foreign countries.

Napier said he wanted out of the National Socialist

White People's Party because of the Party breaking into

splinter groups.

He also objected to the leadership of the

National Socialist White People's Party.

Napier was questioned about any information he

might have concerning possible secret groups being formed

in the Los Angeles area and he stated he had heard about

a group called the Secret Army Organization that was in

Napier claimed the only contact he had with the Secret Army

Organization was from a pamphlet he had received from this

group, setting forth the aims and ideas of the organization.

He said they are strictly anti-communistic and Pro-American

in their approach.

Napier denied that he had any affiliation

whatsoever with the Secret Army Organization.

On February 9, 1971

By JERONE

I contacted the mystery man last night at

Denny's Restaurant and it turned out to be ISAAC CANTRELL.

He told me that he previously lived in Arizona and

because of some trouble or difficulty there, moved to

Los Angeles, California.

He said he believed he had been followed to

Los Angeles.

He subsequently moved to the san Diego area

and is now living in Alpine.

We talked about his recent arrest on charges

of violating firearms laws and he said the charges

against him have been dismissed. He said he thinks

the local authorities are still watching him, and that

they may try to arrest him again if they get the chance.

He said he still has most of his stuff for

working on firearms but indicated that the articles which

were confiscated at the time of his arrest had not been

returned to him.

As an additional note of interest, he told me :

he had been in contact with BOB DE PUGH and

WALTER PZYSON

at Phoenix, Arizona, approximately three months before

they were arrested.

I plan to proceed slowly in my contacts with

CANTRiLL as he may be a set-up for the local or state

authorities.

EXPERIENCING COMMUNITY

THE TORI EXPERIENCE

The TORI community starts with several

experiences designed to build a sense of com-

munity, and to deepen personal growth.

Stemming from these experiences, the

community unfolds and emerges. Each mem-.

ber has an opportunity to participate in this •

process and to influence the unfolding in

significant lays. The community becomes

• a powerful medium for personal change.

Members trave an opportunity to relate in-

tensely and openly to many others in a variety

of situations. They are free to try out new

ways of being and doing. Each participant

is responsifie for his own learning, and has

a variety o: options and choices during the

weekend. Each person, in a significant sense,

creates his own experience and his own com-

munity environment.

The TORi experiences (trust, openness,

realization, and interdependence) emerge

from the community interaction. They are

seen as central to the growth of the person

as well as to the development of community.

The basic TORI theory will be presented by

Dr. Jack R. Gibb as it is applied to the build-

ing of a sense of community in classrooms,

neighborhoods, congregations, families, and

the total school or business system.

Sandra La Boon, who will be conducting

the workshop, has worked with Dr. Gibb over

the past two years in a wide variety of group

NW 55009 DocId: 32989524 Page 1203

experiences. She has conducted groups with

the Center, Y.M.C.A.'s of Los Angeles and

San Diego and with the Methodist Church.

She is currently conducting research with Dr.

Gibb on the TORI theory.

DESIGN

The community is built upon 24 hours of

experiences over a three-day period. Parti.

cipants should plan to attend for all 24 hours.

No observers will be admitted although parti-

cipants will have freedom to participate in an

experience or not. We start after dinner, 7:30

PM on Friday. The Experience ends 5:00 PM

on Sunday. It is not necessary to stay over

night at the Inn.

CLOTHING

The dress should be comfortable and in-

formal, so you can sit on the floor and go

barefooted or wear socks.

SCHEDULE

Friday night from 7:30 pim. - 11:00 p.m..

Saturday from 9:00 a.m. - 11:00 p.m.

Sunday from 9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.

MEALS

Meals are an integral part of the experience

and participants should plan to have all meals

with the group. There is no additional charge

for meals.

Cost of the training is S25.00.

The training will be in the evening November 22, 23, and 24th, 7:30 to 10:00 P.M. at the National Center

8080 El Paseo Grande, La Jolla, California.

In order to be eligible to take the leader training it will have been necessary for each potential leader to

have experienced a complete TORI weekend.

For the first time we will be providing a program to train leaders in conducting the TORI Community

Experience.

JANUARY BULLETIN

A new year is upon us and there is much to report both good and bad concerning

our struggle for a free America.

We will dwell shortly on the bad news first: Many of you have inquired about

the fate of Thomas K. Stewart who has been indicted on several counts of Armed

Robery stemming from a series of very successful raids against the Socialist

Worker's Party and The Young Socialist Alliance. The trials on all these charges

are atill pending and Mr. Stewart 1s out on $30,000.00 bond at this time. The

arrangements of legal council and tactics have kept a number of the staff here at

the National Coordinating Center busy for quite some time. The cost of all this

as you can well imagine has been very high, but it is our sworn auty to do all we

can for Patriots such as Tom Stewart. As for more information about the case,

the logal aspects are better if we make no public comment. at this time.

Suffice it to say that the cases are heavy on our minds at this time.

we will soon be over our goals there.

steady pace,

MARCH 10, 1971

BY JEROME

PETER RUPLINGER was contacted yesterday and

the photograph of MORRIS STARSKEY was shown to him.

He

said that for sometime now, he has been trying to find out

Who STARSKEY is and has even been following him from time

to time looking for a chance to pick up his briefcase.

RUPLINGER said he has also been following LEON NOWERS

around

the campus, the

last time being the day before yesterday.

He said on

that day, NOWERS went to the Student Placement

Office, where he reviewed the files maintained there on

FBI and CIA employment.

He said he believes possibly

NOWERS was looking for names of students who are applying

or have applied for work with these Government agencies.

There is a rumor going around that the Minutemen

may try to stage some opposition to any san Diego area

anti-war activities to be held on 4/15/71.

To the best oi my knowleage, I have not heara of

any Mn or other right wingers being involved in a Confederate

skirmish unit at Ramona, California, as reported in yesterday's

Evening Tribune.

BY JEROME

It has been leared that last Friday, SAM DAVIS

was doing a lot of talking about shooting people. He said

even il he eventuarly leave this area, he wire make some

they broke up.

DAVIS said he was in favor of killing her because

she apparently knew too much and wanted to set up a shooting

accident at the ranch to get rid of her.

GEORGE HOOVER

vetoed. the idea however, and they. let her retum to Germany..

Last Sunday, at the Gunsmoke Ranch, it was observed

that a complex range

there are as many as 50 persons present.

April 7, 1971

Report of Jerome

PETER RUPLINGER was contacted this morning.

He

claims that there will be nine buses going from San Diego

State to the anti-war demonstration at San Fransisco on

the twentyfourth of this month. He said he will find out

later from where and when

they

are leaving and how many

people will be on the buses.

He knows about the $900 given

the demonstrators by the school and will try to find out if

they get any more money from other. sources.

STAN MO DADE was also contacted this morning and

was accompanied by HONARD CLEVELAND. It was learned that

NC DADE and HOWARD GODFREY were at Camp Pendleton yesterday

looking at the scrap parts pile of the Ordnance Disposal

unit there.

They believe there may be several complete

weapons of various kinds which could be made from the scrap

For this reason they are considering submitting a

bid on the some forty tons of

scrap which is to be sold.

It was learned that JOHN BUSH. is also going to enter a bid.

MC DADE and CLEVELAND indicated they are going to

the deseret in the morning to spend several days doing some

shooting and exploring.

Jerome

I have heard there will be an American Legion

march in downtown San Diego on Sunday, 4/4/71, to protest

the court-martial of Lt. WILLIAM CALLEY. This march

is being sponsored partially by Radio Station KSON and all

Right wing groups in the San Diego area are being urged

to join in.

A call has been put out for 50,000 participants

to the best of my knowledge, no parade permit has been

obtained from the San Diego Police Department.

I was in

contact with one of the women who is pushing the march. She

has telephone 276-6648.

According to her, the march will

start about 12 NOON from the Navy Recreation Field at Harbor

Drive and Market Street, will proceed up Harbor Drive to

8ch Avenue,

from there to Broadway and then back to Harbor

Drive and the recreation Field for a rally.

The woman

told me they have received 3700 phone alls

since last

night.

She said the march seems to be getting much support

from the military, adding that two Generals and three Colonels

have indicated they will participate in the march in full

uniforn.

WINCHESTER, leader of the Nazi Party Group, Bishop Faction,

at Los Angeles, California.

July 13, 1971

REPORT BY JEROME

Yesterday I was in contact with PETER RUPLINGER.

He is still self employed

as a wholesale diamond dealer.

He

said one of his customers is allegedly an Italian who has

connections with the local tuna fishing association and with

the Mafia. He said he had acquired from this person a

rifle with a silencer which he told RUPLINGER was

a Mafia

assassination

weapon.

He obtained this rifle from RUPLINGER

yesterday evening for $20.00.

The rifle is a British

Enfield bolt action

rifle and a .303 caliber. It has beer

heavily modified with an

extension having been added to the

butt stock and the parts of the receiver assembly missing

exposing the internal working mechanism. The rear sight

is. also missing.

The breech ends of the receiver and barrel on this

rifle are usually threaded with a square cut thread. However

on this rifle,

these parts both have a regular toothed

machine thread which was obviasly done to allow the tille

to be disassembled into two pieces.

The forestock of the rifle is also missing and

a device, reported to be a silencer,

has been added to the

breech end of the barrel. This device is approximately

2" in diameter and 5" long and cylindrical in shape.

There is a ¿" diameter aluminum tube extending from the

forward bottom part of this device along the barrel almost

to the muzzle. . Attached to the muzzle is the regular issue

British flash suppressor for use on the Enfield •303 caliber

carbine.

Most of the metal parts of the rifle have been

coated with black lacquer.

When

assembled, the rifle does not headspace

properly which is apparently due to the threads being worn

ôr a necessary shim missing.

I recontacted RUPLINGER this morning and learned

that the individual he obtained the rifle from is one..

PHILLIP SALUATO, 6766 RoSe Field Drive, san Diego,

California.

RUPLINGER said SALUATO allegedly has

other

weapons including Thompson submachine guns and M-2 carbines

which he will sell. RUPLINGER also said that the silenced

In talking with STAN. MC DADE, I have learned

Indian blood,

consequently, he either

quit or was thrown out of the Nazi Party by. SMITH.

hard

feelings.

nothing.

this sito again at a later date with a metal detector.

I have not heard of anything happening.

will try to do some

stickers and leaflets wherever he can.

I received a telephone call last night from LYLE

MANNING at Richfield, Utah. He has telephone number 801-896-

5262, and gave me his address as Post Office Box 412, Richfield,

Utah. He told me he is now employed taking care of the fair

•grounds and race track at Richfield. MANNING claimed that he

and "DOC" ROBERTS are trying to form a right-wing activist

group at Richfield and asked me to send him all the Minuteman

literature that I could get for him. He also indicated

that he and ROBERTS will be visiting the San Diego area

about the middle of January, 1972. He said the purpose of

their trip will be to obtain all the .30-06 and .308 caliber

ammunition that they can find. He asked me to start looking

around for this ammunition for him.

I visited TOM FORREST's place last night and learned

that somehow he is obtaining a large number of the top halves

for M-16 rifle receivers. Apparently the only real difference

between the M-15 rifle, which is semi-automatic, and the M-16

• rifle, which is fully automatic, lies in be top half of the

receivers. He claims to have no trouble selling all these

items that he can get ahold of and he must have a good source

for suchweapon parts.

Information Center located at 7720 University, La Mesa,

and very much down on the Minuteman organization and related

right-wing activities. He claimed to know all of the Minuteman.

leaders and indicated that he and his group went on maneuvers

with the Minuteman organization all the time. He stated

of both the Republican and Left Wing groups.

each Wednesday night at 7:30 PM which is open to the public.

Yesterday BOB MAYER, STAN MC DADE, SAM DAVIS, NICK

January 17, 1972

by JEROME

Last night BARRY GODFREY told that earlier in the

day two San Diego, California, Police Department, detectives

had come to his house questioning him about the shooting

incident at the residence of Professor PETER BOHMER On

January 6, 1972. GODFREY said the detectives names, SANDERS

and SHIVELY, came on very strong as though GODFREY was a self-

admitted

member of the SAO. They asked what he knew about

the shooting incident and whether the SAO had been involved.

He told them he did not know anything about the shooting

except when he had read the paper, and he did not elaborate

on the SAO. They then asked him whether he had any 9 mm.

weapons to which he replied he did not and that he did not like

that caliber. Following that, they asked him if he knew anyone

in the SAO who had anything to do with the incident and GODFREY

said that he did not. The detectives then said the shooting

incident was a very bad deal, and GODFREY agreed with them

stating it was very unprofessional and that if someone had

really wanted to do something to Professor BOHER, they could

have easily taken the front half of his building off.

GODFREY said the detectives were somewhat interested

in his automobile, and explained to him that they had pre-

viously observed him visiting at the residence of JERRY LYNN

DAVIS.

January 20, 1972

by JEROME

..;

I have learned that the Bulls Eye Gun Shop in El

Cajon, California, has been closed as it was not making much

money. BILL GUIETTE, the former manager, is now hanging around

with a friend named LARRY BROWN at the Jiffy Machine Shop.

Most of the gun shop inventory, including many weapons, is now

located in GUIETTE's garage at his home.

TOM FORREST has a business establishment named

the Tom Forrest Company located in the Midway Industrial Center

on Kurtz Street just off Rosecrans. He is usually there most

HOOVER went to El Monte, California, last Saturday

night to hear MATT KOEHL, National Commander of the

attend the rally at the San Diego NSWPP Headquarters

I went to see BETTIE HAUGHTON yesterday and

got the Minox camera togother with four rolls of film

and three gas masks. She said she is going to leave

town within two weeks.

SAM DAVIS was also with me and

she gave SAM some keys to a garage where all of the

old Minutemen camp gear is located. This stuff includes

cots, stoves, medical supplies, etcetera.

She also

told

SAM that a large quantity of explosives is supposedly

buried under the house of VAL BOYLE, TROY HAUGHTON'S

mother.

I also understand that JIM POTO and FRED

HAWES know something about this garage and hava some

of their stuff stored there too.

HAWES used to live

with BETTIE HAUGHTON and she and JIM POTO are on very

good terms.

When SAM DAVIS and BARRY GODFREY were at the

Yuma Gun Show weekend before last; they met with EV

MOORE and discussed a few details and plans about the

SAO but nothing very extensive.

Apparently, there is

a rumor going around that ROBERT DE PUGH, former National

leader of the Minutemen Organization, may already be

trying to make a comeback even though he is still in

prison. This rumor is based on the fact that certain

Individuals who did a lot of work for him and for the

Ku Klux Klan in the southwest are now highly placed in

the Llberty Lobby which is now setting up survival

groups and an underground organizational and communications

network. It is believed that all of this activity may

be part of plans for DE PUGH to come back and take over

again. One of the individuals involved in these activities

Is ALICE DUNN, who was formerly in the organization named

will be sent out along with a coded coupon which

name, for him to use to request more information if

Interested in the SAO.

MOORE, who is supposed to be a master locksmith,

Indicated he would write a bulletin for the sAd on how

to jimmy doors and also, an advanced training bulletin

on lock picking and safe cracking.

BARRY GODFREY is to be the official SAO

photographer and a part. of his duties will include

taking and editing photographs of SAO training

WAIT GUIRE'S name was

mentioned as one

who might give propaganda

lectures.

suggestions such as keeping a loaded camera by the door

in order to take photographs of the interviewing officials,

obtaining the name and badge number of these officials

and make them wait while the appropriate agency is called

to verify their identity. BETTIE HAUGHTON has said she

once caught some ATFD Agents using FBI identification in

their interviews. These procedures are also a harrassment

tactic which may hopefully frighten away less serious

minded interviewers.

GEORGE HOOVER Claims he has not filed a Federal

of the Lakeside area during the Republican National Convention

UBJECT: Activities of Gerald I. Smith.

On Thursday night, January 4, 1973 Gerald Smith spoke to an evening

class at San. Diego State College. He does not remember the name of the

srofessor in charge of the class but says he teaches advertising and public

relations classes. Knowing what I do about San Diego State College, this

neans that the class is probably held in the Business Administration and

iathematics Building, one of the newest structures on campus. Gerald also

stated that the professor had dark curly hair and sported a beard. The

topic of the speech was the organizational structure of the National Social

White Peoples Party. Gerald states that he was well received by the class

and that there was no harrassment whatsoever. In fact, an invitation has

been extended to joseph Tomnasi via Smith to make a similar appearance

before the same class.

• On Sunday, January 7, 1973 Gene Cubbison of the Independent Newspaper

made a two-hour broadcast over radio station ESDO-Sen Diego. The broadcasi

included discussions of the Secret Army Organization, the FBI, Howard Barry

Godfrey and Gerald I. Snith. Ray Wilson notified Smith that the program
